awd_titl_txt: SaTC: EDU: Collaborative: Building a Low-cost and State-of-the-art IoT Security Hands-on Laboratory
awd_abstract_narration:
The Internet of Things (IoT) interconnects everything including physical and virtual objects together through communication protocols. IoT has broad applications in digital healthcare, smart cities, transportation, agriculture, logistics and many other domains. The popularity of IoT has raised  security and privacy concerns. This project  seeks to improve IoT and privacy education through the development of laboratory module materials. This will include the development of an IoT platform with an industrial grade microcontroller (MCU) equipped with a crypto co-processor that is significantly lower-cost than existing platforms. This platform will allow for the development of a full-fledged IoT laboratory with hardware security modules at a cost that will make it affordable for students and institutions. The proposed IoT platform, teaching labs with both hardware and software, case studies and faculty development summer workshop will help improve curricula, student learning, and faculty collaboration and development at the participating institutes and partner intuitions, including Hispanic Serving Institutions and Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). 

This project is the first to use an industrial grade microcontroller and a crypto coprocessor to systematically develop teaching materials including hands-on labs and case studies on IoT security and privacy. The intellectual merit of the proposed project lies in its development of effective, engaging and novel teaching materials on IoT security. The deliverables include: a low-cost IoT development kit; the integrated development environment (IDE) to use the kit; multiple teaching labs covering the hardware security, secure key storage, secure boot, data security, network security, secure firmware upgrade and crypto co-processor; two case studies on building trustworthy air quality monitoring systems. The investigators will build awareness and competence to respond to a dynamic and rapidly developing array of cyber threats, especially those in the emerging IoT applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The growing popularity of the Internet of Things (IoT) has raised significant security and privacy concerns. Investigations by our team and others have revealed various vulnerabilities in many market-available IoT devices.

Industrial-grade microcontrollers (MCU) have broad applications in IoT. For instance, sensor nodes in various smart systems, such as smart homes, smart health, and smart grids, use MCUs to process commands and perform automatic control. In this project, we developed a low-cost platform featuring an industrial-grade MCU ESP32, equipped with a crypto co-processor ATECC608A for a new IoT Security and Privacy course. Additionally, we created teaching materials, including labs and case studies, for IoT security education.

Recognizing that different IoT systems have different requirements, we developed 23 slide sets covering a range of topics: introductory cryptography, cryptography applications and considerations in IoT, Roots of Trust and attestation, invasive hardware security threats (those involving direct modification), IoT-friendly communication protocols, connecting an IoT device to AWS, and vulnerability identification and threat quantification. We also included several case studies of real-life IoT security breaches. These are complemented by 6 hands-on labs, 2 short-answer homework assignments, and a hands-on final project to ensure student understanding and practical experience.

By educating future IoT engineers through this course, they will be equipped to incorporate these solutions into their future products, directly benefiting our daily lives.

Modified by: Shuo Wang
